figure_1.title: Fig. 2. Number of funded and unfunded articles of Clinics in Orthopedic Surgery.

figure_2.title: Fig. 3. Countries of editorial board members of Clinics in Orthopedic Surgery [cited 2016 Jan 28].

figure_3.title: Fig. 4. Countries of authors of 392 articles published in Clinics in Orthopedic Surgery between 2009 and 2015.

figure_4.title: Fig. 5. Countries of authors who cited Clinics in Orthopedic Surgery articles from Web of Science Core Collection database [cited 2016 Jan 28].

figure_5.title: Fig. 6. Changing pattern of total citations of Clinics in Orthopedic Surgery articles from Web of Science Core Collection database [cited 2016 Jan 28].

claims.sentence: Accordingly, the number of citable articles has also grown during the same period: 378 (96.4%) of the total 392 articles were citable articles (Fig. 1).
The proportion of funded research has fluctuated during the period: 9.4% in 2010 as opposed to 25.0% in 2014 (Fig. 2).
The editorial board consists of 61 specialists in their respective fields from 13 different countries: 25 from Korea, 13 from USA, 11 from Japan, and 12 from 10 other countries (Fig. 3).
Authors of CiOS were from 20 countries: most of the authors were Korean (319, 81.4%), followed by American (22, 5.6%), Japanese (13, 3.3%), and Indian (12, 3.1%) (Fig. 4).
The largest number of citing authors was in the USA (321), followed by Korea (170), and China (132) (Fig. 5).
The total citations of CiOS have increased from 0 in 2009 to 374 in 2015 (Fig. 6).
The impact factor excluding self-citations was the greatest for CiOS among the 4 Asian journals in 2013 and 2014 (Fig. 7).

The proportion of funded original articles (18.4%) was comparable to the following journals (Fig. 2): Diabetes & Metabolism Journal, 43.9%;2)
Clinical and Experimental Reproductive Medicine, 39.8%;3)
International Neurourology Journal, 38.6%;4)
Clinical Endoscopy, 38.2%;5)
Annals of Rehabilitation Medicine, 34.2%;6)
Neurointervention 29.0%;7) and Journal of Educational Evaluation for Health Professions, 29.0%.8) The proportion of funded articles is important in that it can inform researchers of important current topics not only in the academic society but also in a specific country and researchers can learn about the development trends in specific fields based on the observation of funding sources and frequent research topics.

Currently, the editorial board members of CiOS are from 13 different countries; there should be additional recruitment from more than 20 countries to promote submission of manuscripts from all over the world (Fig. 3).

A predominantly large number of articles (366 out of 392, 91.8%) were submitted only by authors from Korea, USA, Japan, and India, which can be overcome by recruiting new editorial board members from a variety of countries (Fig. 4).

Citation of articles by researchers from 66 different countries can be considered an indication that the journal has strived to fulfill the aim of promoting communication regarding orthopedic problems and advanced patient care (Fig. 5).

Considering that most frequently citing journals were all top-notch orthopedic journals, it can be assumed that CiOS has already attained a central position in the network of prestigious orthopedic journals (Fig. 6).

The impact factor without self-citations of CiOS was compared with that of 3 Asian orthopedic journals indexed in Journal Citation Reports, which showed that CiOS attained the highest impact factor among the groups (Fig. 7).
Accordingly, the number of citable articles has also grown during the same period: 378 (96.4%) of the total 392 articles were citable articles (Fig. 1).
The proportion of funded research has fluctuated during the period: 9.4% in 2010 as opposed to 25.0% in 2014 (Fig. 2).

The impact factor excluding self-citations was the greatest for CiOS among the 4 Asian journals in 2013 and 2014 (Fig. 7).

Clinical and Experimental Reproductive Medicine, 39.8%;3)
International Neurourology Journal, 38.6%;4)

Annals of Rehabilitation Medicine, 34.2%;6)
